data.title: Unique Member Numbers
data.solution:
count = gets.to_i
headers = gets.chomp.split(',')
id_index = headers.index('ID')
member_number_index = headers.index('MEMBER_NUMBER')
members = []
count.times do
    row = gets.chomp.split(',')
    members << {ID: row[id_index], MEMBER_NUMBER: row[member_number_index]}
end

members.sort do |a, b|
    a[:ID] <=> b[:ID]
end

members_by_numbers = {}
members.each do |member|
    members_by_numbers[member[:MEMBER_NUMBER]] ||= []
    members_by_numbers[member[:MEMBER_NUMBER]] << member[:ID]
end

duplicates = false
members_by_numbers.each do |_, ids|
    if ids.size > 1
        duplicates = true
        puts ids.sort_by(&:to_i).join(',')
    end
end

puts "NONE" unless duplicates
data.statement:
Your work has tasked you with sorting out some issues with the member numbers. All members should have a unique member number. The problem is someone has created a bunch of duplicate member numbers in your database. You have an incomplete copy of some SQL output from the database table for members. It shows at least the <<ID>> and the <<MEMBER_NUMBER>> for each member. All of the <<ID>>s will be unique. Your job is to return all sets of <<ID>>s from members with duplicated <<MEMBER_NUMBER>>s.

Here is an example of the SQL input:
`5
ID,MEMBER_NUMBER
1,123456789
2,123456780
3,123456780
4,987654321
5,123456789`
The SQL input shows two different sets of rows that have duplicated <<MEMBER_NUMBER>>s. Our outputs should be the <<ID>>s of the duplicated rows sorted by the smallest <<ID>> in the set, with the smaller <<ID>> listed first and the set separated by a comma. The desired output for the above input would be:
`1,5
2,3`
If there are no duplicates, return {{"NONE"}}.
There may be additional SQL columns that can be ignored.

testCases.title: Test 2
testCases.testIn:
5
ID,NAME,MEMBER_NUMBER
1,Jimmy J,123456789
2,Tommy T,123456780
3,Debbie D,123456780
4,Billy B,987654321
5,Cathy C,123456789

testCases.title: Validator 2
testCases.testIn:
5
ID,NAME,MEMBER_NUMBER
2,Jimmy J,123654789
3,Tommy T,123654780
4,Debbie D,123654780
5,Billy B,987654321
6,Cathy C,123654789

data.stubGenerator:
read COUNT:int
read HEADERS:string(1024)
loop COUNT read ROW:string(1024)

write duplicates
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> an integer [[COUNT]] signifying the number of data rows in the input
<<Line 2:>> a string of [[N]] [[HEADERS]] separated by commas
<<Next [[COUNT]] lines:>> rows of [[N]] pieces of member data as <<strings>> separated by <<comma>> with <<no additional white space>>.
data.outputDescription:
[[M]] rows of <<strings>> of two {{ID}}s separated by a <<comma>>, that correspond to rows that had duplicate {{MEMBER_NUMBER}}s.
If no duplicates exist, then a single <<string>> {{“NONE”}}.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Your work has tasked you with sorting out some issues with the member numbers. All members should have a unique member number. The problem is someone has created a bunch of duplicate member numbers in your database. You have an incomplete copy of some SQL output from the database table for members. It shows at least the ID and the MEMBER_NUMBER for each member. All of the IDs will be unique. Your job is to return all sets of IDs from members with duplicated MEMBER_NUMBERs.

Here is an example of the SQL input:
5
ID,MEMBER_NUMBER
1,123456789
2,123456780
3,123456780
4,987654321
5,123456789

The SQL input shows two different sets of rows that have duplicated MEMBER_NUMBERs. Our outputs should be the IDs of the duplicated rows sorted by the smallest ID in the set, with the smaller ID listed first and the set separated by a comma. The desired output for the above input would be:
1,5
2,3

If there are no duplicates, return "NONE".
There may be additional SQL columns that can be ignored.
Input
Line 1: an integer COUNT signifying the number of data rows in the input
Line 2: a string of N HEADERS separated by commas
Next COUNT lines: rows of N pieces of member data as strings separated by comma with no additional white space.
Output
M rows of strings of two IDs separated by a comma, that correspond to rows that had duplicate MEMBER_NUMBERs.
If no duplicates exist, then a single string “NONE”.
Constraints
2 ≤ COUNT ≤ 100
Example
Input
5
ID,MEMBER_NUMBER
1,123456789
2,123456780
3,123456780
4,987654321
5,123456789
Output
1,5
2,3
